snippet: Errors and procedures that may be wasting precious time during emergencies in New York City are highlighted in a highly anticipated report from a consulting company.
abstract: Bloomberg administration releases final version of report on its much-delayed and over-budget new 911 system after controversial efforts at blocking an early draft; study highlights errors and procedures that may slow system's response times. (M)/

byline.original: By DAVID W. CHEN; David M. Halbfinger contributed reporting

lead_paragraph: New York City's 911 emergency dispatch system sometimes sends firefighters or police officers to the wrong address. Operators sometimes waste precious seconds and sow confusion by failing to follow a standard script when taking information from callers. And, sometimes, an emergency operator can ask eight questions about a caller's location and other details, then patch in another operator who asks six more questions, before getting to the most important one: ''What is the emergency?'' Those were among the biggest flaws highlighted in a highly anticipated report released Friday by the Bloomberg administration on its much-delayed and over-budget new 911 system, formally called the Emergency Communications Transformation Project.

headline.main: Report Lists Many Flaws In Handling Of 911 Calls
